ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course was especially helpful in developing analytical skills in dialectical philosophy and in decoding the various forms of argumentation present in various different scholarly traditions. In particular, I appreciate how this course emphasized the importance of confronting different logics with a sense of good-faith.
Fun and cute class! I dont think I learned anything though! :D

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course could benefit from a bit more structure. A lot of the syllabus is tailored to fit between various themes which change from class to class, but at times the central connecting idea--the importance of tradition--seemed secondary to the overall course flow. This phenomenon perhaps arose because tradition gets interpreted and defined differently depending on the particular scholarly history in question or the particular lens of analysis being employed in class that day, but I felt that a clearer network or linking between the various class sessions may have clarified the class's trajectory.
Fun, we learned about Beyonc. Weak because we didnt learn anything of substance!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student. In particular, the philosophy that the course engages with is incredibly rich and the professor has a great grasp on how to encourage a seminar discussion without imposing himself too much. I think in particular this course would be beneficial to those who wish to better understand frames of thinking which fundamentally posit a distinct relationship between humanity and its past.
It's a good class to complete the EP&E core requirements, intellectually stimulating while also being very manageable in terms of workload
